subject: RE: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: Tell that to the Sun API guys -- they throw NullPointerException on null inputs after specifically checking for null -- look at the source. If the API Doc
messageBody:
Tell that to the Sun API guys -- they throw NullPointerException on null
inputs after specifically checking for 'null' -- look at the source.

If the API Doc includes an "@throws NullPointerException" and explains the
conditions under which it is thrown, (ie, you passed in a null argument),
then the "fault" is with the caller - the code is behaving as advertised.

I'd have to agree that an "IllegalArgumentException" might be clearer,
depending on the circumstances.

I'd also have to say that, like a lot of software issues, when to use which
exception or how closely to "guard" a method depends on context.

Ken

At 09:57 AM 9/11/2002 -0500, you wrote:
>The problem is that I don't know if there was a problem with the input,
>the processing or something random. If your code returns an
>IllegalArgumentException, then I have a much better idea of the issues.
>
>Simon
>
> >-----Original Message-----
> >From: STRAYER, JON (AIT) [mailto:jon.strayer@...]
> >Sent: Wednesday, September 11, 2002 9:50 AM
> >To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> >Subject: RE: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
> >
> >
> >>>I disagree. If the input violates a precondition, the fault
> >>>lies with the input, by definition.
> >>
> >> I wholeheartedly disagree with you. It makes no difference
> >> what your "contract" is between a piece of software and it's
> >> callers, if the software doesn't check it's own inputs then
> >> it is at fault.
> >
> >If you pass my code a null reference and my code throws a
> >NullPointerException what's the problem?
> >
